did.abstract: University of Michigan unit established in 1911 to advance culture in the state, assist local communities with technical knowledge, and acquaint faculty with local conditions through course offerings and lectures by university faculty and staff at sites around the state. Records include annual reports of extension activity from 1911 to 1980, director's files, committee minutes, special reports and surveys, and records of lectures and courses given.
did.physloc: Boxes 1-56 are stored off-site, prior notice required for retrieval. Box 57 (audio-visual material) and boxes 58-60 are stored in the library.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The record group (Donor No. 1660) came to the library in various acquisitions beginning in the 1950s. Periodic accessions are received.

accessrestrict.p: The records are open for research with the exception of personnel files located in boxes 46-49 which are closed in accordance with university policy and applicable law.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: item, folder title, box no., Extension Service (University of Michigan) Records, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: The Extension Division of the University of Michigan was formally organized by the Board of Regents in 1911. The major purposes of the Extension Division were to serve the general cause of education and advancement of culture in the state, to provide local communities with the technical and experimental knowledge of the university faculty, and to acquaint members of the various faculties with local conditions throughout the state. The bylaws of the Extension Division also stated that only those areas of university activity which have their roots in campus programs may be carried throughout the state.

The first responsibility of the Extension Division was the management of the Educational Lecture Bureau. President H. B. Hutchins named William D. Henderson of the Physics Department as part-time director of this program. With the support of President Hutchins and the Board of Regents, the scope of the Extension Division's operations grew from the administration of lectures, to a small number of credit classes which began in Detroit in 1913, and then to a program that served nearly a dozen Michigan communities with lectures and credit courses by the mid-twenties.

In the period between 1935 and 1950 the Extension Service experienced tremendous growth. Enrollment increased from 3,500 to 21,000. The main reason for this increase was the opening of six regional offices throughout the state. The first of the offices was established in Detroit in 1935 at the university's Horace H. Rackham Educational Memorial Building. Later offices were set up in Grand Rapids, Flint, Saginaw, Ann Arbor, and Escanaba. The development of regional area offices made it possible to present and develop long-range programs in various fields.

In the post World War II era the Extension Service actively developed new programs and regional offices. Some of these programs flourished, e.g. music, art, gerontology, real estate, and firemanship training; others, the Worker's Educational Program for example, were abandoned. The credit courses offered through the Extension Service gradually became more oriented towards the graduate student. By 1980, nearly 95% of the credit courses offered through the Extension Service were for graduate credit.

The Extension Service was reduced by 90% in 1981. The report of the budget review subcommittee investigating the Extension Service unanimously recommended that the University of Michigan Extension Service should be discontinued as an administrative unit. This included the transfer of all off-campus instruction activities to the appropriate academic unit and the discontinuance or transfer of all credit-free activities.

The Extension Service has had five directors. The first, William D. Henderson, served as part-time director from 1912 to 1919. In 1919 he was appointed director and held that position until his retirement in 1937. Henderson was succeeded by Charles A. Fisher. Fisher had been the assistant director under Henderson and was the director of the Extension Service from 1937 until his death in 1948. Everett J. Soop became director in 1948 and served until his retirement in 1970. Alfred Storey, who had been assistant director, succeeded Soop. He retired from this position in 1989. Glenda Radine, director of the Department of Conferences and Institutes, was appointed as interim director. She served in this capacity until the Extension Service was reconfigured in 1995 and its activities incorporated into the Academic Outreach unit. Academic Outreach, created to manage non-traditional instruction programs and distance education, was dissolved in 1999.

The Firemanship Training Program grew out of the Michigan Fire College that was begun in 1928 to train fire personnel in techniques of fire fighting. The Fire College found a permanent home at the University of Michigan in 1941. The following year, the Department of Extension Services in conjunction with the School of Education set up classes to train fire department instructors. Chief Wallace Gannon of the Muskegon Fire Department came to the school in 1942 to be the instructor for the year. He returned in 1946 and was full-time instructor until 1953. In 1943, the program was expanded to include off-campus courses in fire fighting techniques. The programs became very popular and from 1946 to 1960 over 15,000 fire fighters participated in these programs.

With demand rising for these programs, it was soon apparent that a permanent facility was needed where residential training could take place. A new facility was proposed in 1955 and the Civil Defense and Disaster Training Center was completed in 1959. Francis Hartman, who had been involved with the program from the beginning, became the first director of the new center and program. He was succeeded by Arthur Appel who retired in 1978, and was succeeded by Robert Schultz, former assistant director, in 1978.

The first residential fire school at the new facility was held August 17-28, 1959. This new building provided for even further expansion of the program. The courses offered were expanded to include three residential schools in fire training-- basic, intermediary, advanced--, a longer 240-hour academy, and numerous yearly conferences in the areas of arson control, fire chief training, industrial fire control, fire instruction, state property fire control, and civil defense training.

The 90% reduction in Extension Services in 1981 had its effect on the Firemanship Training Program. Money was no longer available to support the program as before and offerings and enrollments were declining. In 1991, the program was transferred to the Housing Division, Department of Conferences and Seminars. The last residential fire school was held in July 1992. The department continued to offer the various conferences and seminars until 1994 when they canceled all offerings except for a conference on fire control. The Civil Defense and Disaster Center is currently used by the Ann Arbor Fire Department as a substation.

In 1995, the Extension Service, as an independently functioning University department, was abolished and its services incorporated into Academic Outreach. This office was created to coordinate the University's increasingly varied efforts to extend its educational mission of teaching, research, and service beyond the University's residential campus. One of its major responsibilities is to find constructive ways to expand the University's learning environment through technology. The University of Michigan Virtual Campus and the Michigan Virtual Auto College are examples of several resultant programs. Academic Outreach was disbanded in 1999. Several of the unit's responsibilities were transferred to the Media Union as well as to other units on campus. (See University Record, February 22, 1999 "Media Union to Provide Learning Technology Support" for information on the dissolution of Academic Outreach.)

arrangement.p: The records of the Extension Service are organized into six series: Director's Files, Central Files, Histories, Firemanship Training Program, Audio-Visual Material and Academic Outreach Files.

scopecontent.p: The records of the Extension Service document the university's efforts to extend its educational efforts beyond the campus. The records include annual reports of extension activity from 1911 to 1980, committee minutes, special reports and surveys, and records of lectures and courses given throughout the state. Topics include adult education, continuing education, work in several Michigan communities, and files relating to civil defense and disaster training, firemanship training, World War II management and science training programs, and gerontology. Documentation includes files of directors William Henderson, Charles A. Fisher, Everett J. Soop, and Alfred W. Storey. Of note are records of Charles Follo relating to extension work in the Upper Peninsula.

scopecontent.p: The Director's Office Files, dated 1912-1994, include the Extension Service's annual reports, minutes of the executive committee and staff meetings, financial records, enrollment records, and topical files. Also included are specific reports and surveys and the personal files of the first three directors: William D. Henderson, Charles A. Fisher, and Everett J. Soop. The bulk of material in the Director's Office Files are the Topical Files. There are four separate runs of topical files: 1912-1959, 1959-1972, ca. 1936-1980 and 1950-1994. The topical files are arranged alphabetically. Some of the more important files concern adult education, Extension Service conferences and institutes, civil defense and disaster training, and the Michigan Coordinating Council of State College Field Services.

scopecontent.p: The Topical File, ca. 1936-1980 in part continues the subjects listed in the 1982 accession. The most significant file is the "Evaluation and Planning Project." This was a university-wide project begun in 1973 in response to the budget crisis of the 1970s. The project was conducted in three phases: I) articulation of unit objectives and operations implications; II) evaluation of operations in light of objectives described in phase I; and III) exploration of directions and alternative courses of action. The file includes a number of internal and external reports and studies, questionnaires, and statistics on enrollment, funding and expenses. It provides an interesting look at the Extension Service's goals and objectives and the range of its programs in the early 1970s. Other significant files include the High School Correspondence Studies Reports, Community College Advisory Committee, the Rackham Building (Detroit) anniversaries, and Washtenaw Community College.

scopecontent.p: Topical Files, 1950-1994 contain background and planning information on the various extension services centers around the state of Michigan, individual courses and programs, as well as materials related to the Extension Service's history, objectives and self-assessment. General histories are included as well as information on specific school and college offerings. The bulk of these records are from the 1970s and early 1980s.

scopecontent.p: The Central Office Files consist of area office records. These files contain the records of the Detroit, Flint, Grand Rapids, Saginaw, Traverse City, and Upper Peninsula offices as well as files relating to Extension Service activities in other Michigan cities. The records concerning the Detroit office contain materials from the Ann Arbor central office and files from the Rackham Educational Memorial Building in Detroit, which have been interfiled.

The Course, Lecture and Instructor Files consists mainly of card file indexes to extension courses and lectures, dated approximately 1911 to 1981. The cards include name of instructor, subject, date and location of the course or lecture.

scopecontent.p: The Histories series includes both brief sketches and more extended treatments of the development of the Extension Service and its various sub-units. These were written between the 1930s and the 1970s. Additional histories of individual area offices may be found under the names of the respective cities in the Central Office Files.

did.unittitle: Extracts From Regents Proceedings Regarding Extension Service

scopecontent.p: The Firemanship Training Program series is composed mostly of material relating to the education of fire personnel and includes mostly course material. The series is divided into several subseries; Background, Correspondence, Fire Schools, Seminars and Conferences, Civil Defense and Disaster Training Center, and Topical Files. Photographs relating to these materials may be found in the Audiovisual series

The Background subseries contains material relating to the founding of the program and its expansion after the construction of the new facility. Included in this series are correspondence, reports, newspaper clippings and magazine articles. The Correspondence subseries provides information about the later years of the program from 1976 to 1990. It is arranged in chronological order.

The two largest subseries are Fire Schools and Seminars and Conferences. These two series contain materials relating to the main focus of the program, fire fighter training and education. The Fire Schools subseries contains announcement brochures, enrollment numbers, course schedules and material, exams, lecture guides and instructor's manuals. Information is provided on basic, intermediate and advanced fire schools, the 240-hour academy, industrial fire brigades and town and regional fire schools. The material is arranged alphabetically by topic or type of school.

did.unittitle: Associate in Firemanship Training Job Description 1968
Instructor's Manual in Elementary Fire Service Training 1951

scopecontent.p: The Seminars and Conferences subseries contains handouts, course material, and announcement brochures. Offerings included: fire chiefs training, fire instructors training, fire detection and arson investigation, industrial fire control, and state property fire control. This subseries is arranged alphabetically by type of seminar and then chronologically by date of the seminar.

did.unittitle: Fireman Officers' Training Conference, Course Materials
Fireman Officers' Training Conference, Upper Peninsula 1961
Civil Defense and Disaster Training Center (Fire Building)

scopecontent.p: The Civil Defense and Disaster Training Center subseries relates to the fire training center and its many uses. Information is provided on the building itself, the uses of the building and its history. Material consists mainly of correspondence and some reports.

The Topical Files subseries contains some office files and material on other activities of the program and is arranged alphabetically. Included in this subseries is material relating to the publication and film, "The Firefighter and Electrical Equipment."

did.unittitle: International Association of Arson Investigators Arson Conference 1975-1976
State Advisory Committee for Fireman Education 1955

scopecontent.p: The Audiovisual Materials series contains five subseries, Audiotapes, Films, Photographs, Slides, and Video Tapes.
The Audiotapes subseries contains one audiotape reel that contains a lecture, ca. 1952, on the history of firemen's training in Michigan and the Extension Service's Fire College.

did.unittitle: Lecture on History of Firemen's Training in Michigan, Extension Fire College 1952

odd.p: (possibly by R. C. Loughead)

scopecontent.p: The Films subseries contains one film, "Learning For Living," produced ca. 1944, which documents the work of the Extension Service. It includes brief footage of President Alexander Ruthven (silent), Extension Service Director C. A. Fisher, and E. J. Soop, then head of the Detroit office, as well as shots of the Ann Arbor campus and the Rackham Educational Memorial Building in Detroit. A phonograph recording, "The Promise of Living" by the Rackham Choir, has been transferred to the library's audio collection.

odd.p: (outsized location Y381B)

scopecontent.p: The Photograph subseries is located in box 57 and one outsize folder (UBImum/C470). This material is arranged alphabetically according to the subject of the photographs. All photographs are black and white and there are some negatives included with the corresponding prints.

Ann Arbor Campus Buildings photographs include images of the Bell Tower, the Horace H. Rackham Building, interiors of the Rackham and Hill Auditoriums and an aerial view of the University of Michigan Stadium and the entire Ann Arbor campus.

Courses and Programs photographs (prints and contact prints) contain classroom shots of the courses offered in gaming, art, Great Lakes research, adult education, real estate, and radio broadcasting, including two prints of Joseph Maddy in the WJR studio. Extension Service Centers (prints and negatives) photographs include images of Extension Service Centers in Ann Arbor (no negative), Dearborn, Detroit, Grand Rapids, Flint, and Saginaw. The Rackham Memorial Educational Building photographs also include three prints of university and city officials at the laying of the building cornerstone, and six prints of the Rackham building.

The Firemanship training program photographs make up a large portion of the Courses and Programs photographs. The photographs are separated by topic and arranged alphabetically. The largest group of photos are the class photos for the residential schools, which range from 1959-1981. Also included are photographs of training at the Civil Defense and Disaster Center and town schools. Photographs of staff members include Wally Gannon, Francis Hartman, W. Tackaberry, B. Parrot. Arthur Appel and Robert Schultz are pictured in various class portraits.

Staff Members includes photographs, most of them identified, of Extension Service staff, including Al Storey, Dan Brown, and William D. Henderson, Extension Services Director from 1919 to 1937. There is also a set of photographs of Everett J. Soop, Extension Services Director from 1948 to 1970.

odd.p: (including the Bell Tower, aerial view of the stadium, aerial view of the campus and dorm buildings)

scopecontent.p: The Slides subseries contains 76 color slides with an index, of Extension Service Centers in the state of Michigan as well as classroom scenes. This set may have been used for presentation purposes.

odd.p: (includes the Henry Ford Centennial Library, Dearborn Campus, registration activities and a map of Extension Service Centers in Michigan)

did.unittitle: Hearth Video (Nursing Online Computer Mediated Communications System) 1995

scopecontent.p: The Academic Outreach series offers some documentation on the development of the Academic Outreach office and decisions to determine the focus and thrust of the office. Material represented here relates primarily to the extension functions continued by the successor office. Several of the files reflect efforts to utilize technology as an outreach and extension activity.
